titleStmt.title: A declaration published in the Scots army, proclaimed by order from Generall Leven at Durham, May 13. 1646. With a declaration and orders from the Estates of Scotland, dated at Edenborough, May 8. concerning the King, and those that repaire to him. With the heads of other papers from Newcastle, concerning the manner of His Majesties entertainment there, and the posture of the said garrison, upon His Majesties comming thither. With two victories againt the enemy in Scotland. Two of Colkittoths brothers slaine. These papers are perused, and commanded to be printed.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: A DECLARATION publi≈øhed in the Scots Army, Proclaimed by Order from Generall LEVEN at Durham, May 13. 1646.
WITH A DECLARATION and ORDERS from the E≈øtates of Scotland, Dated at Edenborough, May 8. concerning the KING, and tho≈øe that repaire to him.
With the Heads of other Papers from Newca≈øtle, concerning the manner of His Maje≈øties entertainment there, and the po≈øture of the ≈øaid Garri≈øon upon His Maje≈øties comming thither.
With two Victories again≈øt the Enemy in Scotland.
Two of Colkittoths Brothers ≈ølaine.

p.hi: The≈øe Papers are peru≈øed, and commanded to be printed.

div.p: LONDON: Printed for Matthew Walbanck, May 21. 1646.

div.head: Heads of Papers from Newcastle, concerning the King and the Scotti≈øh Forces: With a Declaration publi≈øhed at Durham, and Orders from the E≈øtates at Edenborough.
div.p:
AS the coming of his Maje≈øty was ≈øtrange and unexpected to the Generall and Commi≈ø≈øioners of the Scots Army, ≈øo it was admired by all the Officers and Souldiers; yet ≈øeeing, that it hath plea≈ød Almighty God to throw his Maje≈øty upon them, they tell us, that they will u≈øe their uttermo≈øt endeavours to make the be≈øt improvement therof that God ≈øhall
inable them to, for the good of both Kingdomes, the maintaining of the Covenant, the ≈øetling of the Church, and procuring of a ≈øafe and well-grounded peace to both Nations.

Since His Maje≈øty ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ me to Southwell, there came divers Malignants to the Army, which number daily increa≈øed, ≈øo that by that time the K. was marched to Durham: there were many mixed among the Scots ≈øouldiers, and ≈øome came thither al≈øo afterwards.

But his Excellency, the Earle of Leven, and the Commi≈ø≈øioners, taking into con≈øideration the dangerous con≈øequence thereof (if not timely prevented) & adverti≈øements being had about the ≈øame, (both to maintaine the Covenant, and the
peace of both Kingdomes) they thought fit that a Declaration ≈øhould be publi≈øhed, That all per≈øons what≈øoever, that have done any di≈ø-≈øervice again≈øt the Parliament, ≈øhall not remain in, or come neer the Army, before they have ≈øubmitted to the Authority and all Ordinances of Parliament.

And accordingly on wedne≈øday, the 13. of May, 1646. the ≈øaid Declaration was drawne up, and ≈øigned by His Excellencie, with the advice of the ≈øaid Commi≈ø≈øioners, and commanded to be publi≈øhed throughout all their Quarters: And the ≈øame day His Maje≈øty being to pa≈ø≈øe away from Durham to Newca≈øtle, the Proclamation was accordingly proclaimed in Durham, as followeth:

div.head: By his Excellencie the Earle of Leven, Lord Generall of the Scoti≈øh Armies, and with the advice of the Right Honourable Committee, re≈øiding with the Armie.
div.p: THe≈øe are ≈øtrictly to require all Officers and Souldiers under my command, to forbeare to have any dealing, or entertaine any corre≈øpondencie, or beare company upon the march, or in any the quarters with any per≈øon what≈øoever, formerly in ≈øervice again≈øt the Parliament of England, nor to have the lea≈øt compliance with any di≈ø-affected thereto: But upon notice of their being in the Army, forthwith to ≈øignifie the ≈øame, that they may be removed, and that wee may be ju≈øtified in the integritie of our intentions, and the better to prevent all mi≈ø-under≈øtanding of our wayes‚ñ™

It is hereby Declared, That no ≈øuch per≈øons applie them≈øelves to come neere to
this Armie, but to ≈øeparate and depart, untill they give all due obedience to, and ≈øubmit to the Ordinances & Authoritie of Parliament, certifying them, and every of them, That if after publi≈øhing of the≈øe pre≈øent Orders, they be found in the Army, in manner above≈øaid, they are not to be protected, but reputed and e≈øteemed as Enemies, their per≈øons to be ≈øeized on and delivered by you: And hereof all per≈øons what≈øoever, are to take ≈øpeciall notice, as they ≈øhall an≈øwer the contrary upon their perill.

signed.hi: For all Officers and Souldiers under my command, and for all other whom the≈øe may concerne. Signed LEVEN.

div.p:
And the E≈øtates of Scotland have di≈øcharged all per≈øons what≈øoever, to ≈øeek or receive any Gift, Pen≈øion, or mark of honour from His Maje≈øtie, and appoynted, that no other de≈øire be propounded to him, but to
≈øatisfie the joynt de≈øire of both Kingdoms, in ≈øetling of Religion & peace.

When the Declaration was publi≈øhed in Durham, it did no little vex the Malignants, of which ≈øort there are good ≈øtore in tho≈øe parts, who hoped to have found better acceptance, and from thence encouraged them≈øelves (as they ≈øuppo≈øed and much wi≈øhed) that the Parliament of England and their Armies, and the Kingdome of Scotland and theirs would have begun a new warre; and to kindle the≈øe coales, many were very active, not only verbally, but in publike action; but ble≈ø≈øed bee God, the Cockatrices were cru≈øhed in their ≈øhels.

The Generall made many faire and full expre≈ø≈øions (before hee left
Durham) of the integrity of the Kingdome of Scotland towards the Parliament of England, and e≈øpecially in the ob≈øervance of the Nationall League and Covenant; And the Committee of E≈øtates for the Kingdome of Scotland, ≈øitting at Edenborough, have publi≈øhed this Order and Declaration throughout the Kingdome of Scotland.

div.head: By the Committee of E≈øtates, for the Kingdome of Scotland.
div.p:
THe Committee of E≈øtates, taking to their con≈øiderations the pre≈øent condition of the publique affaires of this Kingdome, doe find it nece≈ø≈øary, in regard thereof, and for divers cau≈øes, much importing the advancement of this Cau≈øe, & good, & peace of this Kingdom, that a re≈øtraint be upon all the Subjects of this
„Äà1 page duplicate„Äâ
„Äà1 page duplicate„Äâ
Kingdome, from going out of the ≈øame without publike Warrant.

And for that effect, the Committee doth Ordaine and command, the Lyon Herald, and his brethren Heralds and Pur≈øevants, to pa≈ø≈øe to the Market-Cro≈ø≈øe of Edenborough, and there, by open Proclamation, to command, charge, and inhibit, all his Maje≈øties Subjects, of what degree and condition ≈øoever they be, that none of them pre≈øume nor take upon hand to go out of this Kingdome, by Sea or Land, without Warrant of the Committee of E≈øtates, under the paine to be pur≈øued and puni≈øhed, as publique enemies and contemners of the publique Orders of the Kingdome, with power hereby. And Ordaines this re≈øtraint, to continue till the fir≈øt day of June next comming.
div.trailer: To all Governours of Garri≈øons, and all Officers, Judges, Magi≈øtrates, and others to whom it doth belong, to take and apprehend all ≈øuch per≈øons as they find going out of the Kingdome, without a Pa≈ø≈øe as afore≈øaid.

closer.dateline: Dated at Edenborough this 8 of May, 1646.

div.p: Al≈øo for the Army of the Scots, they marched very long and hard marches from New-ark; and his Maje≈øtie was on the ≈øaid Wedne≈øday the 13 of May in≈øtant (about five of the clock in the after-noon) received by the Governour of New-ca≈øtle into the towne, without any ≈øolemnitie, or ringing of bels, ≈øhooting of Cannon, or acclamations of the people, as ≈øome would have had it done.

His Maje≈øtie entred the towne in a generall manner, the Souldiers ≈øtanding to their Armes from Gate≈øhead to the place where his Maje≈øtie was to quarter; where the Governor taketh care that the King may be attended with all the circum≈øpection he can, that the di≈ø-affected have no acce≈ø≈øe unto his Maje≈øtie.

And the better to prevent the ≈øame, there are appointed Burge≈ø≈øes to wait, two at everie port in the town, and there is not a Scotti≈øhman to be received from Scotland, without a Pa≈ø≈øe from the E≈øtates; and no Engli≈øh-man from any place of England, except they be men of tru≈øt and fidelitie, and approved of by the Parliament, their Commi≈øsioners, or the Deputy-Mayor of New-Ca≈øtle. And ≈øince his Maje≈øtie, and the Scotti≈øh Nobilitie
came to New-Ca≈øtle, they have di≈øcharged divers Cavaliers of the Kings attendants.
Something more is referred to this following Letter.

body.p: LA≈øt night being Wedne≈øday in the evening the King came to Newca≈øtle, his Maje≈øties entertainment was briefly thus „Äà‚óä„Äâ . A lane of muskets, and pikes was made (by order from Sir James Lun≈ødale the Governour) from Gate≈øhead (the place where his Maje≈øty entred this town) all along the ≈øtreets, to the Generalls own quarters, where his Maje≈øty now lyeth; there came with his Maje≈øtie about 300. hor≈øe, or ≈øcarce ≈øo many, and very few or none of the Countrey Gentry come with his Maje≈øtie into the towne, of any quality, which was prevented by Inhabitants of tru≈øt, which were placed both at the Gates, and before the Court, (viz. the Generalls Quarters where his Maje≈øtie ≈øtill is) and the≈øe did very carefully di≈øcry and prevent the entrance of all Delinquents, and admitted no ≈øu≈øpected Engli≈øh per≈øons, to enter into the Towne, and upon ≈øearch, they found none that were of any e≈øteeme or repute. That watch was continued not only that day, but ≈øtill is to continue from day, to day; and they have ≈øecured ≈øome, and feared the malignant party in the≈øe parts, and kept them in awe, that they dare not pre≈øume to attempt to come near the King.

Generall Leven hath received a Letter from the Engli≈øh Commi≈øsioners from Lincoln, to whom it was directed, with their de≈øires to acquaint the re≈øt of the Commi≈øsioners of Scotland (re≈øiding here with the King) therewith, which accordingly was this day done. The ≈øub≈øtance of which Letter is;

p.q: That to prevent the coming of Malignants to the King, upon his moving Northward, they de≈øire that no countenance, nor any encouragement at all ≈øhould be given to the Malignant partie (which ≈øhall come neere the King, by his Maje≈øtie. And the ≈øaid Commi≈øsioners do al≈øo de≈øire the accommodation of the Scots, in what they ≈øhall repre≈øent to them, in relation to that bu≈øine≈ø≈øe, and for the better ob≈øervance thereof.

body.p: This Letter being delivered to the Generall, his Excellency acquainted the re≈øt of the Lords therewith, who taking the ≈øame into con≈øideration, gave their con≈øent thereto, and what hath been ob≈øerved therein produceth good effect, and the chiefe≈øt of the Scotti≈øh Nation that are here, do a≈ø≈øure us thus much:

p.q: That the Parliament of England will not be denyed what they ≈øhall de≈øire, concerning the Malignants of the≈øe parts.

body.p:
And whereas there hath been Proclamation made at Durham, by order from the Generall, and the re≈øt of the Commi≈øsioners, that whoever upon the Kings motion or re≈øidence in the≈øe parts, ≈øhall refu≈øe to ≈øubmit to the Orders, and Authority of Parliament, ≈øhall be puni≈øhed according to their demerit, which al≈øo I believe will bee publi≈øhed in this place, where they have kept from the King divers per≈øons, concerning whom they have received adverti≈øements from the Commi≈øsioners, „Äà‚óä„Äâ Lievtenant Colonel „Äà‚óä„Äâ
K ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
and others.

p.hi: Now for the manner of his Maje≈øties march into Newca≈øtle, with the hor≈øe that came along with him and his attendants, it was in brief in this manner.

body.p: 1 There marched in a partie of Hor≈øe into New-Ca≈øtle towne by the way of Gate≈øhead, who marched thorow the Lane made from thence along the ≈øtreets to the place appointed for his Maje≈øtie, which was the Generals quarters.
2 Some that attended upon his Maje≈øtie, rid before all bare.
3 Then his Maje≈øtie marched with the Generall, and ≈øome other Scotti≈øh Officers, divers of whom al≈øo that were neer the King, rid bare.
4 There went none out of the towne of New-Ca≈øtle to meet his Maje≈øtie, neither the Scotti≈øh Lords that were in the towne, nor the Deputy-Mayor thereof; nor any other, either Inhabitant or other.
5 His Maje≈øtie was not received in any triumph (as ≈øome would have had it to have been done) nor did they in any ≈øolemne manner take notice of his Maje≈øtie.
6 The King rid in a ≈øad coloured plaine ≈øuit, and alighted at the Generals quarters (now the Court.)
7 There were no guns di≈øcharged, neither by land nor by water, by way of triumph.

8 There was no acclamation by ≈øhooting with muskets, ≈øounding of trumpets, or beating of drums, and yet there were both Kettle-drums, and trumpets good ≈øtore in New-Ca≈øtle; yet were they ≈øo far from any publike way of triumph, that they did not found or beat ≈øo much, as when one troop of Scotti≈øh Hor≈øe march into New-Ca≈øtle.

p.hi: I pray God that things may be accommodated, according to the Parliaments de≈øires, and that a right under≈øtanding may bee on both ≈øides, that ≈øo all unlucky jealou≈øies may bee removed, and unity, love, and peace, be confirmed according to the Nationall League and Covenant.

body.p: Now concerning the Kingdom of Scotland, ≈øeeing that it hath plea≈øed God to give good ≈øucce≈ø≈øe to the Scotti≈øh forces there, as appeares by Letters from Edenborough, bearing date May the 10. in≈øtant; I ≈øhall communicate to you the particulars of tho≈øe expre≈ø≈øes that we have received from the ‚Ä¢ nconcerning the ≈øame, which is briefly thus.

1 That the Marque≈ø≈øe of Argile hath ≈øent over to Argile and Eilah a partie of 1200 men, who found part of Colkiltoths Forces before Eilah, and marched up to them to releeve the Ca≈øtle, and fell upon them, and after a ≈øharp encounter killed 140 upon the place, routed the re≈øt, and ≈ølew one of Colkiltoths brothers, who had the command there, and releeved their owne friends in Eilah Ca≈øtle. The ≈øaid 1200 were mo≈øt part Voluntiers,
and ≈øuch as fled out of Argile.

2 There were 1600 men more of the Marque≈ø≈øe of Argiles Forces (from the We≈øt of Scotland) ≈øent to releeve Skipinoth Ca≈øtle, where Colkiltoth him≈øelfe then was, who hearing thereof, as al≈øo of the rai≈øing of the Siege, and routing of his Forces before Eilah Ca≈øtle, everie one moved Ala≈øtor Mac-Do ‚Ä¢ ell (who is called Colkiltoth) to attempt to ≈øtorme, that place before Argiles forces came up, who fir≈øt ≈øent in a ≈øummons, and had a po≈øitive denyall, and then drew up his men to ≈øtorme, which he did very fiercely; but was beaten backe with great lo≈ø≈øe, and in this fight Colkiltoth lo≈øt (another) his elde≈øt brother, who was ≈ølaine upon the place with divers other con≈øiderable men, and the place is relieved, and the ≈øiege rai≈øed, Colkilt ‚Ä¢ th and the re≈øt being fled.

3 Colkiltoth was pur≈øued by the 1600. men of the Marque≈ø≈øe of Argile, who ≈øtill followed him ≈øo clo≈øe, that he with tho≈øe he hath left, was forced to retreat to the Hills, and the Countrey of Argile is now totally cleared of them, they being all fled with Colkiltoth up to the Hills.

4 Major-Generall Middleton is gone up to Mon ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ e, with a re≈øolution to fight with him, and the E≈øtates in Edenborough write, that they expect every day to heare that he is ingaged with him, which it is probable we ≈øhall heare by the next: for at the date of the former Letters they were then verie neare engagement.
